fw.hi: A N A L B E R T P I C K H O T E L YOUNGSTOWN 1, OHIO

div1.p: I noticed your interesting comments concering Tibbles in the Saturday Evening pPost.
My name is Noel Harman, eldest son of Neil K. Harmon and I recall with deep nostaliga the many interesting times that I visited your home with my parents and my beloved Aunt Flora Gregory (Brown).
In fact some 40 odd years ago you took me fishing in the man made ditch along with a local carpenter named Mr. Allen.
I recall one particular night that the catfish were running that we made a rather spectacular catch which incidentally I have never equalled since.

div1.p: Some nights later we tried it again depending on the same good fortune only to end up with pan fried potatoes as the main course.
Those are all treasured memories and while your literary influence was not personally catching you did instill in that young boy a continuing affection for all that is good in our great outdoors.

I am now 52 years old and live in a suburb of Cleveland and work for The General Electric Company as an communication Engineer in Westlake Ohio, all my interests from a boy of 14 have been in the electronic field. In fact had my first "wireless" in Bancroft when 15 years old prior to the days of vacumvacuum tubes.

My Father, N. K. Harman and my mother live in Omaha, Nebraska as also does my brother Gordon. They are quite well and my Father has been Vice President of an insurance company for many years although now on partial retirement because of his age.

fw.hi: A N A L B E R T P I C K H O T E L YOUNGSTOWN 1, OHIO

div1.p: Bancroft is not quite the same somehow. I used to travel all of Nebraska, Colorado and Wyoming and had many opportunities to revisit there a few years ago.
I have done some quail (Bird) hunting in Arkansas some 15 years or more ago but never used a gun, preferring to take colored movies of the action and scenery.
We passed through your white River country on the way down but never had the opportunity to stop in and say hello.
May I extend again my new deep gratitude for the joy you gave me in the teaching an appreciation of our great outdoors
